subj-group.subject: Non-Standard Responses to Taxation: Tax Salience and Tax Morale

abstract.p: We investigate how administrative efficiency affects tax compliance. The context is a German church tax that builds on voluntary compliance. In a field experiment, we inform taxpayers about a reduction in collection costs. We find counteracting effects on compliance, depending on baseline tax morale: High tax morale types do not respond if costs are shifted to a third party, but increase tax payments in response to a true cost reduction. The latter finding establishes that reciprocity is a component of tax morale. Low tax morale types do not reciprocate cost reductions and free-ride on cost shifts.
